title: Ticket #6326: Python bindings core dump when used with Python 3
description:
In ticket #4146 a first pass at compiling the Python bindings against python3 was done. However, there are reports of the resulting library failing to work (core dump), and perhaps not even passing our Python regression tests.

Current guess is there is a problem where our bindings call out directly to the Python interpreter (i.e. something changed semantically in the python developer api, or perhaps our binding code is not as strictly typed as it should be and we are running into trouble passing void pointers). One sensible future-proofing approach to fix this issue would of going through Boost.Python for everything and thereby hopefully avoid calling the python api directly at all.

First step is to reproduce the failing behavior (hopefully via the regression tests) with python3 by building on a recent version of Fedora (at least until #6327 is resolved), then create patches (hopefully by converting fully to Boost.Python) to fix the problems revealed.

---

Current test status:

tests/classad_tests.py: 40 tests, all pass
tests/htcondor_version_tests.py: 5 tests, all pass
tests/htcondor_tests.py: 23 tests, failures=1, errors=1

The couple remaining errors are not python3-specific.
remarks:
2017-Jun-29 16:55:31 by edquist:
At first i was having trouble getting the condor build to use python3, even when it was installed. (I used the python34(-devel) packages from epel.)

Apparently one way to get the condor build to use a particular version is: 

diff --git a/build/cmake/CondorConfigure.cmake b/build/cmake/CondorConfigure.cmake
index d379dee..ec860f8 100644
--- a/build/cmake/CondorConfigure.cmake
+++ b/build/cmake/CondorConfigure.cmake
@@ -82,7 +82,9 @@ message(STATUS "********* BEGINNING CONFIGURATION *********")

 # To find python in Windows we will use alternate technique
 if(NOT WINDOWS AND NOT CONDOR_PLATFORM MATCHES "Fedora19")
+	set(Python_ADDITIONAL_VERSIONS 3.4)
 	include (FindPythonLibs)
+	message(STATUS "CCE: Got PYTHONLIBS_VERSION_STRING = ${PYTHONLIBS_VERSION_STRING}")
 	# As of cmake 2.8.8, the variable below is defined by FindPythonLibs.
 	# This helps ensure we get the same version of the libraries and python
 	# on systems with both python2 and python3.
@@ -90,6 +92,7 @@ if(NOT WINDOWS AND NOT CONDOR_PLATFORM MATCHES "Fedora19")
 		set(PythonInterp_FIND_VERSION "${PYTHONLIBS_VERSION_STRING}")
 	endif()
 	include (FindPythonInterp)
+	message(STATUS "CCE: Got PYTHON_VERSION_STRING = ${PYTHON_VERSION_STRING}")
 else()
 	if(WINDOWS)
 		#only for Visual Studio 2012

(Thanks Jamie for helping me figure this out.) So for now we can still use EL based systems for this.

At the moment i'm still having build issues with boost_python3 missing, but we're on our way.

2017-Jul-05 11:46:06 by edquist:
The problem with the boost_python3 requirement on EL systems was there is no separate boost-python3 package, and the boost-python package is built against python2. So that seemed to mean it wouldn't work to use the native packages (ie, PROPER build) for boost-python and python3.

As an alternative, I tried doing a UW_BUILD, which builds boost as an external, but there were a ton of errors compiling boost python for the boost external; maybe it's just the version used (boost_1_49_0) ?

Anyway I switched to fedora-26, which is python3-only, and which has the separate boost-python3 package. There were a couple of compile errors related to char vs wchar_t strings, which might make sense because of the way python3 makes everything unicode. After fixing those, the build now succeeds.

I have my changes here for the moment, but I can push this to a branch on the condor afs repo too.
https://github.com/edquist/htcondor/compare/master...p3

Todd T, do we have a recipe for reproducing the core dumps with python3?

Brian B had suggested working though any errors in the python-bindings tests, eg: 

cd ./src/python-bindings
./test_driver tests/classad_tests.py
./test_driver tests/htcondor_version_tests.py
./test_driver tests/htcondor_tests.py

Currently there are a bunch of errors, but it might just be that the python test scripts are making python2 assumptions (as opposed to things being broken in the C++ python bindings code).

2017-Jul-06 10:57:30 by edquist:
So far for the fedora-26 python3-only situation, there were some errors that were clearly just python2 vs 3 -isms in the tests (eg names of returned types), but some functionality appears to be pretty broken too.

Just the following: 

classad.ClassAd({'a': [1,2, {}]})
fails with: 
RuntimeError: Unable to convert mapping to keys

which happens here:
https://github.com/htcondor/htcondor/blob/V8_7_2/src/python-bindings/classad.cpp#L899

2017-Jul-06 11:30:02 by bbockelm:
I suspect I know what is going on here.

In Python 2, a C object could implement the mapping protocol by having the appropriate function names (keys(), items(), values()). In Python 3, the mapping protocol is implemented by filling in the correct PyMappingMethods in the C type object.

2017-Jul-06 12:15:47 by bbockelm:
Ok, here's a somewhat close example: https://github.com/CymricNPG/cpython/blob/enum/src/module.cpp#L39

Basically, after class creation, extract the raw PyTypeObject, make a copy of it, and set the tp_as_mapping to a new mapping object.

Now, that code demonstrates doing this for a class instance. To do it for a class type, I think you can use something like this: 

        boost::python::type_info info = boost::python::type_id<ExprTreeHolder>();
        const boost::python::converter::registration* reg = boost::python::converter::registry::query(info);

        PyTypeObject* type_obj = reg->get_class_object();

Probably need to set reg->m_class_object member variable directly.

2017-Jul-06 12:44:12 by bbockelm:
Hm - actually, I take that back. Looking at the cpython source code, we actually should still be calling keys() here.

It might be helpful to narrow down precisely which object it is complaining about.

2017-Jul-06 21:38:06 by bbockelm:
Oh - I just saw the update about not being able to reproduce the crashes.

I thought the crashes mostly occur in the tests for the htcondor module (while the classad issues were unit test failures...).

2017-Jul-07 14:05:49 by edquist:
We've been making progress fixing the failures from classad_tests.py ...

https://github.com/edquist/htcondor/compare/master...p3

The next failures are with test_parse_iter, which I am guessing has something to do with the underlying FILE pointers in the python file objects. In particular, classad.parseAds(fh).next() sets the file position for fh to the end of the file, where in python2 it stopped after the first ad.

If anyone thinks time would be better spent on getting htcondor_tests.py working first, feel free to let me know. That one actually failed out for me with some permissions issues before getting to any actual crashes.

2017-Jul-07 14:07:49 by bbockelm:
I think it's pretty easy to argue that the classad unit tests should be "easier" to fix (while providing experience in working with boost python). htcondor unit tests failures will be ... difficult.

So, let's keep on with the same strategy! I would suggest that we try to review / merge the code for classad before moving on to htcondor. Breaking up the review will make it more manageable.

2017-Jul-11 15:55:53 by edquist:
I've been trying to track down a failure for this test: 
classad.parseOne("foo = 1\nbar = 2")

There appear to be some issues related to iterator logic, which tests for the presence of a next attribute -- which iterators have in python2, but in python3 the method is called __next__.

For example, here: https://github.com/edquist/htcondor/blob/p3/src/python-bindings/classad_parsers.cpp#L203

The m_source_has_next variable is based on the presence of the next method of a python list, but that method is called __next__ in python3.

Brian B, I tried to just correct this everywhere by making a macro for "next" / "__next__" based on the python version, but this doesn't quite seem to fix the issue... Can you take a peek and see if I'm doing something obviously wrong here?

https://github.com/edquist/htcondor/commit/08fbdb5bce47b2e9a0d3ab13b401d4b9225309e4

2017-Jul-12 18:59:19 by edquist:
The code 
classad.parseOne("foo = 1\nbar = 2")

which dies with 

SystemError: <Boost.Python.function object at 0x7fcaca5bec90> returned a result with an error set
from a StopIteration

Is happening here:

https://github.com/edquist/htcondor/blob/p3/src/python-bindings/classad_parsers.cpp#L156

and makes its way here:

https://github.com/edquist/htcondor/blob/p3/src/python-bindings/classad_parsers.cpp#L174

Which means this tests for PyErr_ExceptionMatches(PyExc_StopIteration) is failing, even though it is (apparently) for a StopIteration exception.

https://github.com/edquist/htcondor/blob/p3/src/python-bindings/classad_parsers.cpp#L169

2017-Jul-13 12:47:12 by bbockelm:
Are you sure it's in that catch block? Did you catch it with GDB or something?

Typically, the error message indicates that the Python C API was used and triggered a Python exception. Then, the function subsequently returned a python object without clearing the python exception first. If you are really at line 174, then it seems the code block is left with either the python error cleared - or a C++ exception is thrown. (Hence, it seems unlikely the issue goes through there.)

When the boost-python / C++ bindings are used, they tend to convert Python exceptions into C++ exceptions.

2017-Jul-18 19:19:15 by edquist:
Brian, do we need to add a call to PyErr_Clear() inside the PyErr_ExceptionMatches(PyExc_StopIteration) block here for the success case too?

https://github.com/edquist/htcondor/compare/p3...p3.debug#diff-7baf982730e6d91f959cbdc077085022R320

Currently PyErr_Clear() is only getting set here, when the StopIteration is explicitly thrown:

https://github.com/edquist/htcondor/compare/p3...p3.debug#diff-7baf982730e6d91f959cbdc077085022R326

2017-Jul-19 13:28:26 by edquist:
Yeah, it seems to me like this issue is the OldClassAdIterator::next() catches and handles a StopIteration error, but does not call PyErr_Clear(). In Python 3, this somehow gets upgraded to a SystemError('<Boost.Python.function object at 0x...> returned a result with an error set',)

This behavior apparently got added in Python 3.5 to _Py_CheckFunctionResult which gets called from the underlying PyObject_Call.

https://bugs.python.org/issue23571

... So I think this means we need to call PyErr_Clear() right before returning successfully from the PyErr_ExceptionMatches(PyExc_StopIteration) block:

https://github.com/edquist/htcondor/compare/p3...p3.debug#diff-7baf982730e6d91f959cbdc077085022R345

(... Brian, let me know if you think I'm on the wrong track here...)

2017-Jul-19 17:00:37 by edquist:
This seems to clear it up... We'll see if any other places pop up that also should be doing a PyErr_Clear but aren't...

https://github.com/edquist/htcondor/commit/034728707cfc8bc486a9c256fb99e43ce47e8cf2

The next errors have to do with parsing classads from python file-like objects. For some reason, in Python 3, the python object's file pointer (.tell()) is always set to the end of the file, despite the underlying classad library doing fgetc calls advancing a character at a time.

But as noted in convert_to_FILEptr, it's dubious that python3's file-like objects can be safely converted to a FILE *

https://github.com/edquist/htcondor/blob/p3/src/python-bindings/classad_module.cpp#L66-L69

2017-Jul-20 17:05:13 by edquist:
So perhaps to re-iterate, the situation is:

- in Python 2, when parsing a classad file, the python file object's FILE pointer is used directly, which gets used by the parser from the classad library. Advancing the file position via calls to getc and ungetc then gets reflected in the python file object.

- in Python 3, there is no FILE pointer available for file-like objects, but we access the underlying fd and with that we use fdopen to make a new FILE pointer. When getc and ungetc calls are made to the FILE pointer, the position reported by ftell() no longer corresponds to the actual fd's file position.

One idea was to extend the ClassAdFileIterator class to contain the python file object also, and calls to next() would call seek on the python object to reset it to match ftell() on the FILE pointer ... But this feels messy.

Another approach which looks to work is to make our FILE object from fdopen() unbuffered, so that getc calls do not advance the fd position beyond what ftell() would report, and replace ungetc calls with fseek(_file, -1, SEEK_CUR) (since ungetc does not actually update the fd position). This is a performance hit since it means one read system call per byte, but I'm not sure if there is a much better option... Open to ideas.

2017-Jul-20 17:28:07 by edquist:
All classad tests now pass; on to the htcondor tests...

2017-Jul-26 11:21:26 by edquist:
Hey Brian, the remaining python3-specific test failures both appear to be schedd related (RuntimeErrors: "Failed to connect to schedd" and "Error when performing action on the schedd"). Not sure what the best way to make progress is with these. (Debugging was a bit easier with the classad tests since each test was independent and could be done by hand in an interactive python session - where the htcondor tests seem to have a bunch of context from the bootstrapping.)

2017-Jul-27 15:41:03 by edquist:
Brian helped track down the schedd errors - turned out the python tests needed to set additional *_PORT env vars (at least when there was an already-running condor). Also apparently there was some weirdness with assertNotEqual and classad objects that had an overloaded '==' operator.

Anyway, that's the last of the python3 failures! Per Brian's review, I've merged my topic branches into master.

The two remaining have been around for a while failing for python2 also. We can open a separate ticket for them:

2017-Aug-08 16:50:23 by edquist:
One follow-up note -

Todd T had suggested trying to build with Python 3 on RHEL 7 using Anaconda Python 3.5, which is apparently the setup the space telescope people are using.

Turns out Anaconda Python is not to be confused with the redhat package called anaconda, which is the system installer. I got anaconda python from https://www.continuum.io/downloads - specifically https://repo.continuum.io/archive/Anaconda3-4.4.0-Linux-x86_64.sh

Using a PROPER build (ie, non-UW_BUILD), I can get the python bindings to compile with anaconda python 3.x on RHEL 7, but the link step fails because ld can't find -lboost_python3 ... That's right, RHEL 7 has the python2 version of boost_python -- specifically, linked against libpython2.7.so.1.0. boost_python3 is apparently only available in later versions of fedora.

So... I think this means that for python3 on RHEL 7 we need to do a UW_BUILD with the updated boost external. I think that task is in progress (ticket no.?) but not yet complete. ([52032])

2017-Aug-10 15:03:31 by edquist:
Tim T has updated the boost external to version 1.64.0. With anaconda python 3 installed, I did a cmake configure with 

../configure_uw -DPYTHON_VERSION=3.6 -DPYTHON_INCLUDE_DIR=$HOME/anaconda3/include/python3.6m -DPYTHON_LIBRARY=$HOME/anaconda3/lib/libpython3.6m.so ..

Which picked up the correct anaconda python version (installed under the user's homedir). However, the boost external failed to build with 

./boost/python/detail/wrap_python.hpp:50:23: fatal error: pyconfig.h: No such file or directory
 # include <pyconfig.h>
                       ^
compilation terminated.

pyconfig.h is in the configured PYTHON_INCLUDE_DIR, so I think this means somehow boost needs to know about PYTHON_INCLUDE_DIR but doesn't.

2017-Aug-10 16:05:27 by edquist:
Yeah i'm not having any luck with this. Apparently PYTHON_INCLUDE_DIR needs to be taken into account for the boost external (so, presumably somewhere in externals/bundles/boost/1.64.0/CMakeLists.txt) ... I'm not sure where though.

2017-Aug-22 17:03:32 by edquist:
I was able to get boost-1.64 (the version used in our externals) to build against anaconda Python 3 on RHEL 7, with some tweaking:

- the version of anaconda python I was using from the site https://www.continuum.io/downloads was Python 3.6, which when installed was called 3.6m ... This m in the version ended up causing some weird compile time errors for the boost external, which expected to find the python include dir under $PYTHON_ROOT/include/python$VERSION, with version 3.6. It correctly detected PYTHON_ROOT using the python3 from PATH (set in ~/.bashrc), but the actual include directory was $PYTHON_ROOT/include/python3.6m. The fix that ended up working was to create a symlink in that include directory from python3.6 -> python3.6m.

After that symlink tweak, I was able to get a condor UW_BUILD to compile against the non-system anaconda python3 install on RHEL 7. To configure the UW-style build to point to the anaconda python, which I installed under ~/anaconda3/, I used: 

mkdir bld3
cd bld3
../configure_uw -DPYTHON_VERSION=3.6 -DPYTHON_INCLUDE_DIR=$HOME/anaconda3/include/python3.6m -DPYTHON_LIBRARY=$HOME/anaconda3/lib/libpython3.6m.so ..

However, after a successful build, the python-bindings tests apparently have trouble finding some library symbol from boost: 

ana@el7-py35 ~/htcondor/bld3/src/python-bindings $ ./test_driver tests/classad_tests.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tests/classad_tests.py", line 8, in <module>
    import classad
ImportError: /home/ana/htcondor/bld3/src/python-bindings/classad.so: undefined symbol: _ZN5boost6python6detail11init_moduleER11PyModuleDefPFvvE

Some grepping shows that this _ZN5boost6python6detail11init_moduleER11PyModuleDefPFvvE symbol is not present in any .so's that get built as part of the condor build; although it is present in the ~/htcondor/bld3/bld_external/boost-1.64.0/install/lib/libboost_python3.a that gets built as part of the boost external.

Brian B, et al, any idea what I might be missing here?

2017-Aug-25 12:34:55 by edquist:
For the UW_BUILD, the PYTHON_BOOST_LIB was getting set to boost_python, but after our latest boost external update (to 1.64.0), the library when built against Python 3 is called boost_python3 (already the case for PROPER builds).

[52178] fixes the CMake rule to use boost_python3 when building against Python 3, regardless of PROPER vs UW_BUILD.

Per discussion with Todd T, I've committed this to V8_7_3-branch for now.

Yay, the unit tests work now. (with a non-system anaconda python3 install)
